*div1 type="summary"* *p*John P. Austin to Austin, New York, January 1, 1830. Prospects of purchase of Texas by the United States. Terms of recognition of land grants.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*Duplicate*/p*
*p**location_mentioned*New York*/location_mentioned*, *date_mentioned n="01-01-1830">January 1, 1830*/date_mentioned**/p* *p*My dear Sir,*/p*
*p*I took this liberty some few weeks since, which letter I hope came safe to hand. I now confirm its contents, and remark that nothing has been done Publicly, at *location_mentioned*Washington*/location_mentioned*, relative to the *location_mentioned*Texas Country*/location_mentioned*; as the *person_mentioned*President */person_mentioned*was silent on the subject in his message, so also have *person_mentioned*Congress */person_mentioned*been thus far, and it is perhaps probable that any thing in contemplation, either on the part of the *person_mentioned*administration*/person_mentioned*, or the *person_mentioned*Congress*/person_mentioned*, will be delayed until late in the session, to gain time, for *person_mentioned*Mr. Poinsett*/person_mentioned*'s return to *location_mentioned*Washington*/location_mentioned*, or for further advice from *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*. *person_mentioned*Persons however high in office*/person_mentioned*, it is said, and others at *location_mentioned*head quarters*/location_mentioned* whose opinions are entitled to some credit have, I know, expressed opinions favorable to the obtainment of that *location_mentioned*Province*/location_mentioned*, and it is admitted to be understood that this *person_mentioned*Government */person_mentioned*have determined on the measure provided it can be reasonably obtained. But when the thing will be formally moved is uncertain and may depend on many circumstances which are not within my reach to divine. The project is now making some noise in the*location_mentioned* English papers*/location_mentioned*, and perhaps will call forth a protest from *location_mentioned*Spain*/location_mentioned*. Yet it appears probable that sooner or later and I believe ere long, the change will be brought about some how or other by amiable negotiation. There seems (as far as I have been able to learn) a considerable disposition to speculate in the *location_mentioned*Texas lands,*/location_mentioned* which can only be accounted for on the supposition that they will soon belong to the *location_mentioned*U. States*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="01-09-1830">January 9th.*/date_mentioned* Since the above I have reason to believe, (by information received from *person_mentioned*persons */person_mentioned*who have good means of judging at *location_mentioned*Washington*/location_mentioned*) that the *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*negotiations, although in embryo yet; are still going on, and something has no doubt been fixed on by this Government, that is, the acquisition for reasonable considerations, and I further learn, that this *person_mentioned*Govt*/person_mentioned*, will probably not be satisfied with the sovereignty of that *location_mentioned*territory */location_mentioned*alone, but must have something more, that is all the lands they can get, to reimburse the payment and satisfy the people, and make the measure popular. I am also informed, it is (or more properly speaking) will be determined among other things that, all *location_mentioned*grants */location_mentioned*whatever, having relation to that *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*(and particularly land, grants) will be strictly scrutinzed and if found informal, or not duly given, or the conditions of the said grants not fully complied with, will not be recognized as valid by this *person_mentioned*Govt*/person_mentioned*. Those of a fair legal character and whose conditions are fully complied with, will doubtless, on principles of justice be confirmed. I loose no time in giving you this information (in confidence) which I am satisfied comes from a correct *person_mentioned*source*/person_mentioned*. Having the best of opportunity of obtaining the earliest information, and such as can be relied on, as to the views of *person_mentioned*both Governments*/person_mentioned* will give me pleasure to communicate it to you, feeling confident, [it] can but prove of interest, and tend to guard you against *person_mentioned*speculators*/person_mentioned*. A *person_mentioned*special minister */person_mentioned*arrived here a few weeks since from *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*, (one high in favor with its *person_mentioned*President*/person_mentioned*) and now on his way to *location_mentioned*Washington*/location_mentioned*, if not full power to act, is authorized to listen to such proposals as our Govt, may have to offer touching the purchase of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, and there appears on the part of the *person_mentioned*Mexican Govt,*/person_mentioned* a strong disposition to cultivate a friendly feeling with this *person_mentioned*Govt*/person_mentioned*., and at the same time no little jealousy towards the *person_mentioned*powers of *location_mentioned*Europe*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned*, and not without good cause from what recently came to light respecting their views towards both *location_mentioned*Columbia */location_mentioned*and *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*. All of which will attribute much to aid the purchase of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*on more favorable terms, and which I have no doubt now occupies the attention of this Govt, and under existing circumstances should not be surprised if an early transfer took place. Letters from *location_mentioned*Vera Cruz */location_mentioned*state that*person_mentioned* Mr. Poinsett*/person_mentioned* and *person_mentioned*secretary */person_mentioned*had taken passage in the packet ship Virginia to sail about the *date_mentioned n="12-15-1829">15 Dec*/date_mentioned*. for this *location_mentioned*port*/location_mentioned*. We are without news from *person_mentioned*brother Henry */person_mentioned*since last I wrote, which left him at *location_mentioned*Matamoras*/location_mentioned*, to proceed on his second trip *location_mentioned*up the river */location_mentioned*in a few days. With the hopes of soon being favored with a letter, I close in haste, as the packet sails in a few moments*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Jno. P. Austin.*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p*P. S. The enclosed queries, (from the *location_mentioned*daily advertiser*/location_mentioned* of *date_mentioned n="12-31-1829">last thursday*/date_mentioned*) proposed to his *person_mentioned*Highness Prince Paul William of *location_mentioned*Wiirtemberg*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned*, are from a source whence his movements are well known, and fully explain the motives of his *person_mentioned*Highness */person_mentioned*scientific researches.*/p* *p**date_mentioned n="01-22-1830">January 22d 1830*/date_mentioned*.*/p* *p*Dear Sir—*/p*
*p*Referring to above duplicate of my last report leaves me now but little to add further than a confirmation. *person_mentioned*Mr. Poinsett*/person_mentioned* did not arrive in the Virginia as was anticipated, but promised would embark in the Falmouth sloop of war, which remained at *location_mentioned*Sacrificios*/location_mentioned* on the*date_mentioned n="12-22-1829"> 22nd of December*/date_mentioned*. Among the *person_mentioned*Virginia passengers */person_mentioned*were *person_mentioned*Col. José Maria Tornell, Minister plenipotentiary from Mexico to this Govt,*/person_mentioned* and*person_mentioned* Col. Mejia secretary of legation */person_mentioned*with their *person_mentioned*families*/person_mentioned*. They leave *date_mentioned n="01-23-1830">tomorrow */date_mentioned*for *location_mentioned*Washington*/location_mentioned*, where they will meet *person_mentioned*col. -----*/person_mentioned*, referred to in the above, who arrived there some weeks since, as a *person_mentioned*special agent from Mexico*/person_mentioned* and whom *person_mentioned*Col. Tornell*/person_mentioned* says enjoys the unlimited confidence of *person_mentioned*Guerrero*/person_mentioned*. Should I get anything of importance, [I shall] loose no time in communicating it.*person_mentioned* Brother Henry*/person_mentioned* writes from *location_mentioned*Matamoras */location_mentioned**date_mentioned n="12-02-1829">Dec. 2d */date_mentioned*that, that *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned* heretofore so healthy, the last of *date_mentioned n="09-xx-1829">September */date_mentioned*a flood came in, which would have enabled him to go quite to *location_mentioned*Sante Fe*/location_mentioned*, but he was unable to avail himself of it, for it brought with it a pestilence which prostrated every body and that he was the only one of the *person_mentioned*boat's crew*/person_mentioned* who escaped it. He had made a second trip to *location_mentioned*Camargo */location_mentioned*and on his return trip had but *person_mentioned*two well men*/person_mentioned* and when he wrote was thus unable to move the boat as his *person_mentioned*engineer */person_mentioned*and men were too feeble to do anything. I hope you have communicated with him as it might prove mutually advantageous.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*John P. Austin. */person_mentioned* [Rubric]*/p* *p**person_mentioned*Col. Stephen F. Austin, */person_mentioned**location_mentioned*San Felippe de Austin, Texas.*/location_mentioned**/p*
